Nese and Yusuf Kara and Sarunya Somsong and Xin Qiao and Kuo Wang},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.2.5},   url = {https://github.com/kamataak/bspam}, }

what: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: bspam R package contains functions fit speed-accuracy psychometric model repeatedly measured count outcome data (Potgieter, Kamata & Kara, 2017; Kara, Kamata, Potgieter & Nese, 2020), accuracy speed modeled binomial count log-normal latent variable models, respectively. example, use modeling technique allows model-based calibration scoring oral reading fluency (ORF) assessment data. document demonstrates uses bspam package using ORF assessment data set.

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: install bspam package, follow steps . Install remotes package, running following R code. Install bspam running following R code.
code: if(!requireNamespace("remotes", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("kamataak/bspam")

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: bspam can implement fully Bayesian approach calibration model parameters scoring using JAGS Stan. desire use fully Bayesian estimation, please download JAGS Stan software computer. download install JAGS, download installation file https://sourceforge.net/projects/mcmc-jags/files/JAGS/ per operating system requirements follow installation steps. bspam internally uses runjags package interface JAGS. runjags package needs installed separately JAGS installed. Stan can installed following steps explained : https://github.com/stan-dev/rstan/wiki/RStan-Getting-Started. Note steps show installation RStan, bspam uses internal package run Stan code. Please follow installation steps carefully along recommended versions R RStudio prevent issues releated running Stan bspam.

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: required data prepared long-format data, row data unique case, namely, specific task specific person specific testing occasion. context ORF assessment, row data specific passage specific student specific testing occasion. data file can prepared file format readable R. example, CSV formatted data can read R using read.csv() function part base packages. Also, data files statistical software formats can read R functions packages, haven package. example, read_spss() function can used read SPSS formatted data file R. data set minimally contain following 7 variables: (1) individual ID, (2) group ID, (3) testing occasion ID, (4) task ID, (5) maximum number attempts task, (6) number successes task, (7) time took complete task. Note data coming one testing occasion one group, variables (2) group ID, (3) testing occasion ID contain arbitrary constant value, 1’s. Variable names order variables can flexible data frame. running functions package, variable names required variables need specified, shown examples . , data need read R data frame.

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: bspam package comes several example data sets ORF assessment context. demonstrate basic usage key functions package, sample ORF assessment data set used . context ORF assessment, task passage given student read aloud, attempt student’s reading word passage, scored correct (.e., success) . Accordingly, number successes task number words correctly read passage. data set passage2 passage-level student data consisted reading accuracy time data 12 passages 85 students. Although 85 students assigned 12 passages, number passages read 85 students varied 2 12 passages. number students per passage 59 79. small subset data collected Nese Kamata (2014-2018).

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: Load required packages, view example data set passage2.
code: library(tidyverse) library(bspam) View(passage2)

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: Calibrate passages using fit.model() function implementing Monte Carlo EM algorithm described Potgieter et al. (2017). default, standard errors model parameters estimated. allow one increase number Monte-Carlo iterations reps.improve quality model parameter estimates, minimizing computation time. number reps.50 100 realistic calibrations. Also note k.number imputations MCEM algorithm, default 5. Note SE’s model parameters required running scoring() function estimate latent factor scores WCPM scores next step. standard errors model parameters desired, additional argument se = "analytic" se = "bootstrap" needs added fit.model() function. Passage calibration can also done using est = "bayes" option, implements fully Bayesian approach Gibbs sampling Hamiltonian Monte Carlo JAGS Stan, respectively. Currently, Stan used complete data, , students data passages. Otherwise, JAGS used provides faster computations missing observations. Note bspam runs JAGS auto mode, require user supply specifications Bayesian estimation (e.g., number iterations) monitor convergence. standard deviations posterior distributions reported standard errors. specification fit.model() function can look like follows.
code: MCEM_run <- fit.model(data = passage2,                       person.id = "id.student",                       task.id = "id.passage",                       max.counts = "numwords.pass",                       obs.counts = "wrc",                       time = "sec",                       k.in = 5,                       reps.in = 50,                       est = "mcem") MCEM_run Bayes_run <- fit.model(data = passage2,                        person.id = "id.student",                        task.id = "id.passage",                        max.counts = "numwords.pass",                        obs.counts = "wrc",                        time = "sec",                        est = "bayes",                        verbose=TRUE) Bayes_run

what: Scoring: Estimating Latent Factor Scores and WCPM Scores 1
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: order estimate latent factor scores /WCPM scores, scoring() function needs run. Note use output object MCEM_run previous passage calibration phase. default (type = "general"), factor scores (θ\theta τ\tau) standard errors reported. providing argument type = "orf", WCPM scores standard errors also reported. Also, WCPM scores /factor scores, standard errors estimated cases data default. several estimator options standard error estimation options: maximum likelihood (MLE), maximum posteriori (MAP), expected posteriori (EAP), fully Bayesian approach. example, maximum priori (MAP) estimators scoring analytic approach estimating standard errors used.

previous_headings: Basic Usage: Task-level Data Analysis > Scoring: Estimating Latent Factor Scores and WCPM Scores 1
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: estimate WCPM scores observations data set passage2, use scoring() function follows.
code: WCPM_all <- scoring(calib.data=MCEM_run,                      data = passage2,                     person.id = "id.student",                     occasion = "occasion",                     group = "grade",                     task.id = "id.passage",                     max.counts = "numwords.pass",                     obs.counts = "wrc",                     time = "sec",                     est = "map",                      se = "analytic",                     type="general") summary(WCPM_all)

previous_headings: Basic Usage: Task-level Data Analysis > Scoring: Estimating Latent Factor Scores and WCPM Scores 1
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: computations WCPM scores /factor scores selected cases desired, list cases needs provided cases = argument. list cases one-variable data frame variable name cases. format case values : personid_occasion. one-variable data frame can created manually, just like shown . Also, can generated get.cases() function, shown later document.
code: sample.cases <- data.frame(cases = c("2033_fall", "2043_fall", "2089_fall")) WCPM_sample <- scoring(calib.data = MCEM_run,                         data = passage2,                        person.id = "id.student",                        occasion = "occasion",                        group = "grade",                        task.id = "id.passage",                        max.counts = "numwords.pass",                        obs.counts = "wrc",                        time = "sec",                        cases = sample.cases,                        est = "eap",                         se = "analytic",                        type = "orf") summary(WCPM_sample)

previous_headings: Basic Usage: Task-level Data Analysis > Scoring: Estimating Latent Factor Scores and WCPM Scores 1
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: Also, can specify set tasks (.e., passages) scale WCPM scores. WCPM scores scaled set passages different set passages student read, set passages referred external passage set ORF assessment context, external task set general. use external passage set particularly important context ORF assessment make estimated WCPM scores comparable students read different sets passages, well within students longitudinal data, student likely read different sets passages. fully Bayesian approach can also used estimator scoring() function. Note est="bayes" specified, need use se= argument. default, standard deviations posterior distributions reported standard errors, along 95% high density intervals, analogous 95% confidence intervals. example using fully Bayesian approach estimating WCPM scores external passages used previous example.
code: WCPM_sample_ext1 <- scoring(calib.data = MCEM_run,                              data = passage2,                             person.id = "id.student",                             occasion = "occasion",                             group = "grade",                             task.id = "id.passage",                             max.counts = "numwords.pass",                             obs.counts = "wrc",                             time = "sec",                             cases = sample.cases,                              external = c("32004","32010","32015","32016","33003","33037"),                             est = "eap",                              se = "analytic",                             type = "orf") summary(WCPM_sample_ext1) WCPM_sample_ext1_bayes <- scoring(calib.data=MCEM_run,                                    data = passage2,                                   person.id = "id.student",                                   occasion = "occasion",                                   group = "grade",                                   task.id = "id.passage",                                   max.counts = "numwords.pass",                                   obs.counts = "wrc",                                   time = "sec",                                   cases = sample.cases,                                    external = c("32004","32010","32015","32016","33003","33037"),                                   est = "bayes",                                   type = "orf") summary(WCPM_sample_ext1_bayes)

what: Scoring: Estimating Latent Factor Scores and WCPM Scores 2
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: Alternatively, can run scoring() two steps. Step 1: Prepare data using prep() function, required data set scoring() function prepared, including changing variable names generation natural-logarithm time data. output prep() function list two components. data.long component data frame, long format student response data, data.wide list contains four components, including wide format data, well information number passages number words passage. One benefit two-step approach can use another utility function get.cases() generate list unique cases output prep() function. list can useful interest estimate WCPM scores selected cases. Generate list unique cases: Step 2: Run scoring() function estimate WCPM scores. Note pass output object MCEM_run passage calibration phase, well manipulated data data.long Step 1. default, WCPM scores estimated cases data. Additionally, several estimator options standard error estimation options. example, maximum priori (MAP) estimators model parameter estimation analytic approach estimate standard errors used.
code: data <- prep(data = passage2,              person.id = "id.student",              occasion = "occasion",              group = "grade",              task.id = "id.passage",              max.counts = "numwords.pass",              obs.counts = "wrc",              time = "sec") all.cases <- get.cases(data$data.long) all.cases WCPM_all <- scoring(calib.data=MCEM_run,                      data = data$data.long,                     est = "map",                      se = "analytic",                     type = "orf") summary(WCPM_all) WCPM_sample_ext2 <- scoring(calib.data=MCEM_run,                              data = data$data.long,                             cases = sample.cases,                              external = c("32004","32010","32015","32016","33003","33037"),                             est = "map",                              se = "analytic",                             type = "orf") summary(WCPM_sample_ext2)

what: Fitting and Scoring by the Testlet Model
title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: example, ORF data consisted sentence-level data, reasonable think data sentences within passage similar data sentences passages. Thus, use testlet-version model reasonable implement. bspam R package can fit score data testlet model MCEM Bayes. example data set sentence.level.data sentence-level student data consisted reading accuracy time data 4 passages 58 students. 4 passages consisted 4 8 sentences, totalling 23 sentences. 58 students read 4 passages completely. small subset data collected Nese Kamata (2014-2018). example testlet model can fitted data set MCEM : estimated testlet parameter reported part hyper-parameters. estimated model paramters can extracted : scoring MAP can done data set :
code: Testlet_run <- fit.model(data = sentence.level.data,                                  person.id = "id.student",                                  task.id = "id.passage",                                  sub.task.id = "id.sentence",                                  obs.count = "wrc",                                   max.counts = "numwords.sent",                                  time = "sec",                                  testlet = TRUE) Testlet_run$hyper.param Testlet_run$task.param Testlet_scoring <-    scoring(calib.data = Testlet_run,           data = sentence.level.data,           person.id = "id.student",           task.id = "id.passage",           sub.task.id = "id.sentence",           obs.count = "wrc",            max.counts = "numwords.sent",           time = "sec",           type = "orf",           testlet = TRUE,           censoring = TRUE)

title: Speed-Accuracy Psychometric Modeling for Binomial Count Outcome Data with R
text: circumstances, test may designed speeded test, many examinees complete tasks test. example, traditional administration ORF test gives student 60 seconds read aloud given passage, typically consisted 250 words. case, many students finish reading entire passage. bspam R package can score data set censored model regular testlet models. Please see package website detailed usage package.

title: agg.word function to aggregate word information to sentence or passage level — agg.word
text: data = word level data agg.level indicator sentence passage level data, default sentence. person.id variable name indicates unique person identifier. passage.id variable name hat indicates unique task identifier. ORF assessment context, passage identifier. word.pos.sen column name represents word's specific position sequence sentence. word.pos.pas column name represents word's specific position sequence passage. sen.pos.pas column name represents sentence's specific position sequence passage. start.time column name data represents start time word read. end.time column name data represents end time word read. time.scale indicator unit reading time, default centi. value can centi (hundredth) sec (second) score column name data represents word correctly read. 0 1 1 means correctly read.

title: agg.word function to aggregate word information to sentence or passage level — agg.word

"T" "F" n.chains int., number chains thin int, thinning interval, .k., period saving samples iter int., number iterations burn-period burn int., number burn-iterations

title: Bayes function when running mcem with bayes setting — bayes.wcpm
text: calib.data - fit.model class object person.data - individual reading data person.id column name data represents unique individual identifier. task.id column name data represents unique task identifier. occasion column name data represents unique occasion. group column name data represents unique group. max.counts column name data represents number words task. obs.counts column name data represents words read correctly case. time column name data represents time, seconds, case. cases - student id vectors, directly use passage data calib.data provided external - NULL, use student read passages estimating type - output type, "general" "orf", default "general" output tau & theta. "orf" output wcpm parallel parallel=T, #logical, run parallel? "T" "F" n.chains int., number chains iter int., number iterations burn-period burn int., number burn-iteration thin int, thinning interval, .k., period saving samples

title: Bayes function when running mcem with bayes setting — bayes.wcpm

what: bspam : A package for fitting the speed-accuracy psychometric model for repeatedly measured count outcome data. — bspam-package
title: bspam : A package for fitting the speed-accuracy psychometric model for repeatedly measured count outcome data. — bspam-package
text: Purpose package `bspam` R package contains functions fit speed-accuracy psychometric model repeatedly measured count outcome data (Potgieter, Kamata & Kara, 2017; Kara, Kamata, Potgieter & Nese, 2020), accuracy modeled binomial count latent variable model. example, use modeling technique allows model-based calibration scoring oral reading fluency (ORF) assessment data. Design philosophy Write Design philosophy

title: bspam : A package for fitting the speed-accuracy psychometric model for repeatedly measured count outcome data. — bspam-package
text: Akihito Kamata <akamata@smu.edu> Cornelis J. Potgieter <c.potgieter@tcu.edu> Joseph F. T. Nese <jnese@uoregon.edu> Yusuf Kara <ykara@mail.smu.edu> Sarunya Somsong <sarunya.ss@hotmail.com> Xin Qiao <xqiao@usf.edu> Kuo Wang <wangkuo@nifty.com>

title: desc.data function to describe data information — desc.data
code: desc.data(   data = NULL,   person.id = NULL,   task.id = NULL,   max.counts = NULL,   obs.counts = NULL,   time = NULL,   sub.task.id = NULL,   desc.level = "sample",   verbose = T,   type = "general",   testlet = F )

title: desc.data function to describe data information — desc.data
text: data data frame data generated prep function. argument used prepared data, next five arguments person.id, task.id, max.counts, obs.counts, time skipped. person.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique person identifier. task.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique task identifier. ORF assessment context, passage identifier. max.counts Quoted variable name data indicates number attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words passage. obs.counts Quoted variable name data indicates number successful attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words read correctly passage. time Quoted variable name data indicates time seconds took complete task. ORF context, time took complete reading passage. sub.task.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique sub task identifier. ORF assessment context, sentence identifier. required testlet TRUE. desc.level Quoted string indicates data summarization. "sample" (default), show description data sample. "person", output summarization person data. verbose Boolean. TRUE, summary output. Default TRUE. type Quoted string, indication choice output. "general" (default), wcpm scores reported. "orf", wcpm scores reported. testlet Boolean. TRUE, runs sub task level, otherwise, task level. Default FALSE.

title: desc.data function to describe data information — desc.data
text: data frame (based sample data person information)

title: Estimate the model parameters — fit.model
text: interface function estimate model parameters based task-level (.e., passage-level ORF assessment context) accuracy speed data implementing Monte Carlo EM algorithm described Potgieter et al. (2017) fully Bayesian method described Kara et al. (2020).

title: Estimate the model parameters — fit.model
code: fit.model(   data = NA,   person.id = "",   task.id = "",   sub.task.id = "",   max.counts = "",   obs.counts = "",   time = "",   k.in = 5,   reps.in = 2,   ests.in = NA,   est = "mcem",   se = "none",   verbose = FALSE,   testlet = FALSE )

title: Estimate the model parameters — fit.model
text: data data frame data generated prep function. argument used prepared data, next five arguments person.id, task.id, max.counts, obs.counts, time skipped. person.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique person identifier. task.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique task identifier. ORF assessment context, passage identifier. sub.task.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique sub task identifier. ORF assessment context, sentence identifier. required testlet TRUE. max.counts Quoted variable name data indicates number attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words passage. obs.counts Quoted variable name data indicates number successful attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words read correctly passage. time Quoted variable name data indicates time seconds took complete task. ORF context, time took complete reading passage. k.Numeric, indicating number imputations. Default 5. reps.Numeric, indicating number Monte-Carlo iterations. Default 2. ests.optional list numeric vectors, indicating initial values model parameters. argument given, mom function called generate initial values. est Quoted string, indicating choice estimator. one "mcem", "bayes". Default "mcem". se Quoted string, indicating choice standard errors. one "none", "analytic", "bootstrap". Default "none". verbose Boolean. TRUE, summary output. Default FALSE. testlet Boolean. TRUE, fit.model.testlet run. Default FALSE.

title: This file includes utilities of bspam package. — prep
code: prep(   data = data,   person.id = "",   task.id = "",   sub.task.id = "",   occasion = "",   group = "",   max.counts = "",   obs.counts = "",   time = "",   cens = "",   sentence_level = FALSE )

title: This file includes utilities of bspam package. — prep
text: data = student response data person.id Quoted variable name person.data indicates unique person identifier. task.id Quoted variable name person.data indicates unique task identifier. ORF assessment context, passage identifier. sub.task.id Quoted variable name person.data indicates unique sub task identifier. ORF assessment context, sentence identifier. required sentence_level TRUE. occasion column name data represents unique occasion. group column name data represents unique group. max.counts Quoted variable name person.data indicates number attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words passage. obs.counts Quoted variable name person.data indicates number successful attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words read correctly passage. time Quoted variable name person.data indicates time seconds took complete task. ORF context, time took complete reading passage. cens column name data represents censoring indicators whether specific task sub task censored (1) fully observed (0). sentence_level flag sentence passage level data, default FALSE

title: This file includes utilities of bspam package. — prep
text: data list (data.long: data frame,                    data.wide: list Y, logT10, N, )

what: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: base function fitting speed-accuracy model estimate model parameters Monte Carlo EM algorithm described Potgieter et al. (2017). function used fit.model function, recommended users use.

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
code: run.mcem(Y, logT10, N, I, k.in = 5, reps.in = 2, ests.in = NA, verbose = FALSE)

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: Y Numeric data matrix accuracy scores size n x , n number tasks number persons. Missing data allowed. logT10 Numeric data matrix time size n x matrix, n defined . time data scale log10(times). Missing data allowed. N Numeric vector passage lengths length n. Numeric, indicating number tasks. k.Numeric, indicating number imputations. Default 5. reps.Numeric, indicating number Monte-Carlo iterations. Default 2. ests.optional list numeric vectors, indicating initial values model param- eters. argument given, mom function called generate initial values. verbose Boolean. TRUE, summary output. Default FALSE.

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: mcem list

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: user desired use function, note response data file needs wide format, can reshaped long-format response data prep.wide function.

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: Update Memo: 10/24/2024 test 04/29/2021 Modified mcem function            based Nelis's updated. 10/28/2021 Modified mcem output

title: Base function for fitting the speed-accuracy model by MCEM — run.mcem
text: Potgieter, N., Kamata, ., & Kara, Y. (2017). EM algorithm   estimating oral reading speed accuracy model. Manuscript submitted   publication.

what: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
text: base function estimating factor scores likelihood-based approaches described Potgieter et al. (2024). function used scoring function, recommended users use.

title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
code: run.scoring(   object,   person.data,   task.data,   cases,   perfect.cases,   zero.cases,   est = "map",   lo = -12,   hi = 12,   q = 100,   kappa = 1,   external = NULL,   type = NULL )

title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
text: object class object. Output calibration phase fit.model function. person.data data frame. long-format response data object. task.data data frame? Estimated task parameter values? cases vector individual id scoring desired. information specified, estimate scores cases person.data. perfect.cases list? list perfect cases. est Quoted string, indicating choice estimator. one code/"mle", "map", "eap", "bayes". Default "map". lo Numeric, indicating lower bound quadratures. Default -12. hi Numeric, indicating upper bound quadratures. Default 12. q Numeric, indicating number quadratures. Default 100. kappa Numeric, indicating ?? Default 1. external optional vector task ID's strings. NULL (default), wcpm scores derived tasks individuals assigned . NULL, wcpm scores derived tasks provided vector, rather tasks individuals assigned. type Quoted string, indication choice output. "general" (default), wcpm scores reported. "orf", wcpm scores reported.

title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
text: wcpm list

title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
text: Update Memo: 04/29/2021 Modified wcpm function            based Nelis's updated. 06/01/2021 Modified based Nelis's MAP function. 06/01/2021 Modified based Sarunya's BiEAP function. 06/20/2021 Modified based Nelis's updated MLE EAP 06/21/2021 Modified bug MAP function. 07/12/2021 Modified est.eqs function based Nelis's code. 07/13/2021 Added Map function bootstrap. 07/30/2021 Modified wcpm function based Sarunya's update

title: Base function for scoring by likelihood-based approaches — run.scoring
text: Qiao, X, Potgieter, N., & Kamata, . (2023). Likelihood Estimation   Model-based Oral Reading Fluency. Manuscript submitted   publication.

what: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
title: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
text: interface function estimated factor scores based task-level (.e., passage-level ORF assessment context) accuracy speed data. implements likelihood-based approaches (MLE, MAP, EAP) described Qiao et al. (review) fully Bayesian method described Kara et al. (2020).

title: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
code: scoring(   calib.data = NA,   data = NA,   person.id = "",   task.id = "",   sub.task.id = "",   occasion = "",   group = "",   max.counts = "",   obs.counts = "",   time = "",   cens = "",   cases = NULL,   est = "map",   se = "analytic",   failsafe = 0,   bootstrap = 100,   external = NULL,   type = "general",   censoring = FALSE,   testlet = FALSE )

title: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
text: calib.data class object. Output calibration phase fit.model function data data frame. necessary  next five arguments person.id, task.id, max. counts, obs. counts, time. person.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique individual identifier. task.id Quoted variable name data represents unique task identifier. ORF assessment context, passage identifier. sub.task.id Quoted variable name data indicates unique sub task identifier. ORF assessment context, sentence identifier. required testlet TRUE. occasion column name data represents unique occasion. group column name data represents unique group. max.counts Quoted variable name data represents number attempts task. ORF assessment context, number words passage. obs.counts column name data represents words read correctly case. time column name data represents time, seconds, case. cens column name data represents censoring indicators whether specific task sub task censored (1) fully observed (0). column necessary censoring argument TRUE. cases vector individual id scoring desired. information specified, estimate scores cases data. est Quoted string, indicating choice estimator. one code/"mle", "map", "eap", "bayes". Default "map". se Quoted string, indication choice standard errors. one code/"analytic", "bootstrap". Default "analytic". failsafe Numeric, indicating number retries bootstrap, can set 0 50. Default 0. external optional vector task ID's strings. NULL (default), wcpm scores derived tasks individuals assigned . NULL, wcpm scores derived tasks provided vector, rather tasks individuals assigned. type Quoted string, indication choice output. "general" (default), wcpm scores reported. "orf", wcpm scores reported. censoring Boolean. TRUE, interface call task sub task censoring. Default FALSE. testlet Boolean. TRUE, runs sub task level, otherwise, task level. argument necessary censoring TRUE. Default FALSE. bootstrp Numeric, indicating number bootstrap iterations. Default 100.

title: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
text: scoring list Bootstrap dataset censoring list

title: Estimate factor scores with task-level model — scoring
text: Additional details...

(2020). Estimating   model-based oral reading fluency: bayesian approach   binomial-lognormal joint latent model.   Educational Psychological Measurement, 1–25.

title: scoring.passage function — scoring.passage.censoring
text: , b: Model parameters related count data model (K-dim) alpha, beta: Model parameters related time data model (K-dim) Count: vector number words correct per passage K-dimensional logT10: log-scale reading time per 10 words per passage K-dimensional N: vector passage lengths K-dimensional sigma: latent standard deviation time latent component rho: correlation count time latent components C: vector indicators whether specific passage censored (1) fully observed (0) – K-dim

title: Bayesian Sampling Models for Passage-Level Observations — testlet_scoring_multi_obs_multi_cens
text: code defines Bayesian sampling models estimating latent variables based passage-level observations specific student. models formulated differently depending number censored (incomplete) fully observed passages. goal estimate latent variables accuracy (theta_acc) speed (theta_spd) student's reading performance.
